facts.text: Kerala High Court answered the referred question in the negative

anchor.surface_text: the High Court of Kerala recorded an answer in the negative. The Company has appealed to this Court with special leave. The Company claims that wealth-tax paid by it represented expenditure laid out wholly and exclusively for the purpose of its business, and on that account is a permissible allowance under s. 10 2  xv  of the Income-tax Act.

arguments.claim: Relating quantum of company wealth-tax liability to profits in special cases does not alter its character as tax on net wealth, not incidental to business

anchor.surface_text: But by relating the quantum of liability of a company to wealth-tax in these special cases to the profits earned, the character of the tax is not altered. It is and remains a tax charged upon the net wealth, and it is not made a tax related to or incidental to the carrying on of a business.

arguments.claim: Deduction under s.10(2)(xv) requires expenditure laid out wholly and exclusively for purpose of business, not capital or personal, arising from trader capacity not owner

anchor.surface_text: To be a permissible deduction, there must be a direct and intimate connection between the expenditure and the business i.e. between the expenditure and the character of the assessee as a trader, and not as owner of assets

arguments.claim: Expenditure deductible only if incidental to business per commercial practice, in trader not owner capacity, as per precedents like Strong & Co v Woodifield

anchor.surface_text: They cannot be deducted if they are mainly incidental to some other vocation, or fall on the trader in some character other than that of trader.

holdings.text: the amount of tax paid on the net wealth of an assessee under the Wealth Tax Act is number a permissible deduction under s. 10 2  xv  of the Indian Income-tax Act in his assessment to income-tax, for tax is imposed under the Wealth Tax Act on the owner of assets and number on any companymercial activity. The charge of the tax is the same, whether the assets are part of or used in the trading Organisation of the owner or are merely owned by him.

anchor.surface_text: In the light of the principles the amount of tax paid on the net wealth of an assessee under the Wealth Tax Act is number a permissible deduction under s. 10 2  xv  of the Indian Income-tax Act in his assessment to income-tax, for tax is imposed under the Wealth Tax Act on the owner of assets and number on any companymercial activity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deduction under s.10(2)(xv) requires direct connection to business in trader capacity; wealth tax levied on asset ownership irrespective of business use or commercial activity.

holdings.text: Tax is charged under S. 3 of the Wealth Tax Act, 1957, for every financial year in respect of the net wealth of every individual, Hindu undivided family and Company [...] The tax under the Act is payable by all individuals, Hindu undivided families ,and Companies on the value of taxable assets belonging to the taxpayer it is charged on the net value of the assets, and number on the business or trading activity carried on by the taxpayer.

anchor.surface_text: Tax is charged under S. 3 of the Wealth Tax Act, 1957, for every financial year in respect of the net wealth of every individual, Hindu undivided family and Company at the rate or rates specified in the Schedule to the Act and net wealth under the Act means the amount by which the aggregate value companyputed in accordance with the provisions of the Act of all the assets belonging to the assessee

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory charging provision s.3 and definition of net wealth impose tax on asset value minus debts on valuation date, applicable to owners regardless of business.

holdings.text: But by relating the quantum of liability of a companypany to wealth-tax in these special cases to the profits earned, the character of the tax is number altered. It is and remains a tax charged upon the net wealth, and it is number made a tax related to or incidental to the carrying on of a business.

anchor.surface_text: But by relating the quantum of liability of a companypany to wealth-tax in these special cases to the profits earned, the character of the tax is number altered. It is and remains a tax charged upon the net wealth, and it is number made a tax related to or incidental to the carrying on of a business. The rules in the Schedule merely extend the exemption

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provisions capping wealth tax at profits for loss-making companies provide relief but do not transform it into a business-related tax.

holdings.text: To be a permissible deduction, there must be a direct and intimate connection between the expenditure and the business i.e. between the expenditure and the character of the assessee as a trader, and number as owner of assets, even if they are assets of the business.

anchor.surface_text: To be a permissible deduction, there must be a direct and intimate connection between the expenditure and the business i.e. between the expenditure and the character of the assessee as a trader, and not as owner of assets

holdings.reasoning_summary: Drawing from precedents and commercial principles, s.10(2)(xv) allows deductions only for expenditures incidental to business operations in trader capacity, justified by commercial expediency.

precedents.citation: The Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. The Anglo Brewing Company Ltd. 1

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. The Anglo Brewing Company Ltd. 1 said that the expression for the purpose of the trade meant for the purpose of keeping the trade going, and of making it pay, he was making that statement in relation to the facts of the case, and he did number intend to suggest a universal test.

precedents.case_name: Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. Anglo Brewing Company Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: the expression for the purpose of the trade meant for the purpose of keeping the trade going, and of making it pay

precedents.citation: Smith v. Lion Brewery Company Ltd. 2

anchor.surface_text: Smith v. Lion Brewery Company Ltd. 2  Ushers Wiltshire Brewery Ltd. v. Bruce 3  and Harrods  Buenos Aires  Ltd. v. Taylor-Gooby.  4  In the Lion Brewery Companys case 2  a Brewery Company who were owners or lessees of licensed premises acquired as part of their business as brewers and as a necessary incident to profitable exploitation were held entitled to the allowance in the companyputation of their income under Sch. D of Compensation Fund Charges imposed under the Licensing Act upon their tenants and which the tenants after paying recouped themselves by deduction from the rents payable to the Company.

precedents.case_name: Smith v. Lion Brewery Company Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: expenditure incurred for payment of rates, taxes and duties held permissible allowance due to special nature of business
precedents.cited_holding: Brewery Company entitled to deduction of Compensation Fund Charges recouped from tenants

precedents.citation: Ushers Wiltshire Brewery Ltd. v. Bruce 3

anchor.surface_text: Ushers Wiltshire Brewery Ltd. v. Bruce 3  and Harrods  Buenos Aires  Ltd. v. Taylor-Gooby.  4  In the Lion Brewery Companys case 2  a Brewery Company who were owners or lessees of licensed premises acquired as part of their business as brewers and as a necessary incident to profitable exploitation were held entitled to the allowance in the companyputation of their income under Sch. D of Compensation Fund Charges imposed under the Licensing Act upon their tenants and which the tenants after paying recouped themselves by deduction from the rents payable to the Company. In Ushers Wiltshire Brewery Ltd.s case 3  the claim of a Brewery Company as owners or lessees of licensed premises acquired in the companyrse of and for the purpose of their business as brewers and as a necessary incident to the more profitable companyduct of their business of certain expenses in companynection with those licensed houses was allow- ed in the companyputation of their profits.

precedents.case_name: Ushers Wiltshire Brewery Ltd v. Bruce
precedents.cited_proposition: expenditure incurred for payment of rates, taxes and duties held permissible allowance due to special nature of business
precedents.cited_holding: Brewery Company allowed deduction for expenses in connection with licensed houses

precedents.citation: Harrods  Buenos Aires  Ltd. v. Taylor-Gooby.  4

anchor.surface_text: Harrods  Buenos Aires  Ltd. v. Taylor-Gooby.  4  In the Lion Brewery Companys case 2  a Brewery Company who were owners or lessees of licensed premises acquired as part of their business as brewers and as a necessary incident to profitable exploitation were held entitled to the allowance in the companyputation of their income under Sch. D of Compensation Fund Charges imposed under the Licensing Act upon their tenants and which the tenants after paying recouped themselves by deduction from the rents payable to the Company. In Ushers Wiltshire Brewery Ltd.s case 3  the claim of a Brewery Company as owners or lessees of licensed premises acquired in the companyrse of and for the purpose of their business as brewers and as a necessary incident to the more profitable companyduct of their business of certain expenses in companynection with those licensed houses was allow- ed in the companyputation of their profits. In Harrods  Buenos Aires  Ltds case 4 -Harrods  Buenos Aires Ltd-a companypany incorporated in the United Kingdom-carried on business of a retail store in Argentina and was liable to pay a tax known as substitute tax which was levied on joint stock companypanies incorporated in Argentina and on companypanies incorporated outside but which carried on business in Argentina through an empresa estable  a companymercial establishment . In proceedings for assessment of income- tax of the business the claim of the Company to deduct the substitute tax paid to the Argentina Government was accepted, for it was an expenditure without paying which the assessee Company companyld number carry on its business at all.

precedents.case_name: Harrods Buenos Aires Ltd v. Taylor-Gooby
precedents.cited_proposition: expenditure incurred for payment of rates, taxes and duties held permissible allowance due to special nature of business
precedents.cited_holding: Substitute tax paid to Argentina government deductible as necessary to carry on business

precedents.citation: Strong and Company of Romsey Ltd. v. Woodifield.  1

anchor.surface_text: Strong and Company of Romsey Ltd. v. Woodifield.  1  That was a case of a Brewery Company owning a licensed house in which it carried on the business of inn-keepers. The Company had to pay damages to a customer who was, when sleeping in the inn, injured by a falling chimney, the fall of the chimney being due to the negligence of the Companys servants. The Company was held disentitled to deduct the expenditure in companyputing its profits for income-tax purposes.

precedents.case_name: Strong & Co of Romsey Ltd v. Woodifield
precedents.cited_proposition: deduction from business profits must be wholly and exclusively laid out for the purposes of the trade and incidental to the trade itself
precedents.cited_holding: Damages paid for injury due to falling chimney not deductible

precedents.citation: Badridas Daga v. Commissioner of Income- tax, 2

anchor.surface_text: Badridas Daga v. Commissioner of Income- tax, 2  Venkatarama Aiyar, J., observed that whether the expenditure is admissible or number will depend upon whether it can be said to arise out of the carrying on of the business and be incidental to it, and this was reaffirmed by this Court in a later judgment in Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Abdullabhai Abdulkadar.

precedents.case_name: Badridas Daga v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: whether the expenditure is admissible or not will depend upon whether it can be said to arise out of the carrying on of the business and be incidental to it

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Abdullabhai Abdulkadar.  3

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Abdullabhai Abdulkadar.  3   1  5 T.C. 215  2  1959 S.C.R. 69034 I.T.R. 10  3  1961 2 S. C. R. 94941 1. T.R. 545. In a recent judgment of this Court Commissioner of Income-tax, Kerala v. Malayalam Plantations Ltd. 1  certain amounts paid as estate duty under s. 84 of the Estate Duty Act, 1953, by a resident companypany incorporated outside India on the death of shareholders number domiciled in India, were sought to be deducted under S. 10 2   xv  as expenditure laid out or expended wholly and exclusively for the purposes of the business.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Abdullabhai Abdulkadar
precedents.cited_proposition: expenditure must arise out of the carrying on of the business and be incidental to it

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Kerala v. Malayalam Plantations Ltd. 1

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax, Kerala v. Malayalam Plantations Ltd. 1  certain amounts paid as estate duty under s. 84 of the Estate Duty Act, 1953, by a resident companypany incorporated outside India on the death of shareholders number domiciled in India, were sought to be deducted under S. 10 2   xv  as expenditure laid out or expended wholly and exclusively for the purposes of the business. Subba Rao, J., speaking for the Court observed at p. 705 The expression for the purpose of the business is wider in scope than the expression for the purpose of earning profits.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Kerala v. Malayalam Plantations Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: the expression 'for the purpose of the business' is wide but the expenditure must be for carrying on the business in capacity as trader not as owner of assets
precedents.cited_holding: Estate duty not deductible under s.10(2)(xv)
